awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Overturning in the Subpolar North Atlantic-the Irminger and Iceland Basins
awd_abstract_narration:
Variability in the transport of heat, freshwater and mass in the North Atlantic has been linked to a number of societally relevant factors including sea level change, the melting of sea and glacial ice, and anthropogenic carbon storage in the deep ocean. However, the current understanding of the drivers of such changes is limited, making an investigation of overturning in the Sub-polar region a key ocean research priority. This field program explicitly addresses this gap. Furthermore, by engaging the larger international community studying the North Atlantic, Overturning in the Sub-polar North Atlantic Program (OSNAP) is playing a key role in catalyzing scientific progress by promoting international collaborations, synthesis, and the sharing of resources and by training future generations. Key to the latter is a network of early career scientists whose professional growth will continue to be facilitated through targeted activities that have been tested and improved during OSNAP's initial phase. Graduate students and post-docs will be trained in seagoing operations and in the processing and analysis of observational data.

The overall goal of this field project, in conjunction with other measurements in the North Atlantic, is to establish determination of the linkage between intermediate and deep water formation and the overturning circulation--a connection that is present in climate models, but has yet to be observed. This project will also provide the first comprehensive view of spreading pathways for the deep waters in the Sub-polar basin. Starting in 2014, the US-led international project, Overturning in the Sub-polar North Atlantic Program (OSNAP), provides a continuous record of the full-water column, trans-basin fluxes of heat, mass and freshwater in the Sub-polar North Atlantic, in partnership with the UK, Netherlands, Canada, Germany and China. Data from the first 21 months of the full OSNAP observing system has been used to produce an initial time series of the meridional overturning, heat and freshwater fluxes for the Sub-polar basin. These preliminary results reveal a highly variable overturning in the basin, interior pathways for overflow waters, surprisingly energetic boundary current systems on timescales from days to months, and a strong overflow plume in the Iceland Basin. The additional two years of OSNAP observations will cover a time frame sufficient to make comparisons with other overturning time series and optimize the OSNAP measurement system--all necessary tasks prior to a request for longer term measurements. This component of OSNAP (OSNAP East) is for the eastern array between Greenland and Scotland in coordination with the UK and the Netherlands. The US contribution includes the East Greenland inshore and offshore arrays, the Iceland Basin array, and the integration of all OSNAP measurements. The sub-goal for OSNAP East is to quantify the structure and transport of the boundary currents off the east coast of Greenland and within the Iceland Basin, as well as determine their variability and forcing mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A system of ocean currents results in the poleward flow of relatively warm, salty waters, towards the Arctic Ocean and around Greenland and the northeastern coast of Canada, and the equatorward flow of relatively colder, fresher waters. Models and historical reconstructions based on sediments, ice cores and other proxies, indicate that changes in this system, known as the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), coincide with pronounced changes in climate especially in the northern hemisphere. Yet the drivers of, and mechanisms behind, these changes happen are largely unknown. This project is part of a large, unprecedented international effort to measure the AMOC, as well as the different currents and processes which contribute to it, in the high latitude of the North Atlantic, the main center of action of the AMOC, for a decade.

 

As part of this project we deployed seven moorings carrying oceanographic instruments that measured the different currents along the eastern side of the Greenland, including the freshwater exported from the Arctic and the Greenland Ice Sheet, the warm waters circling around the basin and deeper denser waters flowing equatorward. These measurements, together with those from several other US institutions as well as contributions from scientists in Germany, the U.K., Canada and the Netherland, have revealed an unexpected degree of variability on interannual timescales. Together with measurements collected as part of the initial phase of this effort and the final phase, they will provide the first assessment of the AMOC in the high latitude North Atlantic for a decade (2014-2024) and offer us the possibility to examine drivers of variability on different timescales, validate models and investigate mechanisms. To date, this record has shown that the AMOC is dominated by processes in the eastern, high latitude North Atlantic and that the AMOC is not simply related to the cooling of the warm waters on these timescales.

 

In addition to the efforts to understand the AMOC, this project has allowed us to investigate the pathways of freshwater from the Arctic region, including the Greenland Ice Sheet, into the large-scale ocean circulation. In one important baseline study, we showed that about half of the Arctic freshwater is mixed into the AMOC upstream of the southern tip of Greenland while the other half flows largely unmodified around Greenland. A second study, investigated the impact of a recent, anomalous accumulation of freshwater in the region south of Iceland that was eventually transported out of the region by ocean currents and mixed into the denser AMOC waters. This anomaly, which we identified as a new Great Salinity Anomaly, has affected the cooling of waters that feed the AMOC and is offering us the opportunity to understand how short-term changes can affect the AMOC. Its effect on the AMOC is now being investigated in a follow up grant. Both these studies offer the opportunity to test hypothesis of AMOC variability and validate models which do not resolve these dynamics accurately.

 

Finally, through this grant we have investigated the addition of freshwater from the melting of the Greenland Ice Sheet. Greenland has been rapidly losing mass over the last few decades resulting in additional fresh water input into the ocean. One future scenario suggests that prolonged melt of the Greenland Ice Sheet will introduce enough freshwater to slow down the AMOC. Before we can answer questions about the impact of Greenland we need to understand how Greenland meltwater is mixed and exported from the glacial fjords which connect the Greenland Ice Sheet and the ocean. As part of this study, we have investigated the export from one fjord, where measurements exist, and showed that it is delayed by several months due to mixing in the fjord. A parallel pan-Greenland study showed that ocean warming impacts the Greenland Ice Sheet, and hence freshwater discharge, especially in southern Greenland.

 

Cumulatively, this project has advanced our knowledge and ability to understand past and future changes of the AMOC and large-scale ocean circulation in the North Atlantic. These are important questions for global societies given that AMOC variability has been linked with impacts worldwide including sea level rise, droughts in the Sahel, carbon sequestration by the ocean, oxygenation of ocean waters and the precipitation patterns over the northern hemisphere. The project has involved over 10 early career scientists (graduate students, postdocs) who have been trained in data collection and analysis techniques and have benefited from the engagement with a large network of foreign partners. Material from this project has also been used in undergraduate courses at UCSD.
